material.mattext: What is the probability of getting a quarter and then a nickel, P(Q1 and N2)?

Incorrect. Using the General Multiplication Rule, P(Q1 and N2)=P(Q1)*P(N2|Q1). For the first pick there are 2 quarters out of 4, so you are right that P(Q1)=2/4. However, given that the first coin was a quarter, there are 3 coins left, two of which are nickels, so P(N2|Q1)=2/3, and not 1/3, as you selected.

Incorrect. Using the General Multiplication Rule, P(Q1 and N2)=P(Q1)*P(N2|Q1). For the first pick there are 2 quarters out of 4, so you are right that P(Q1)=2/4. However, given that the first coin was a quarter, there are 3 coins left, two of which are nickels, so P(N2|Q1)=2/3, and not 1/2, as you selected.

Good Job! Using the General Multiplication Rule, P(Q1 and N2)=P(Q1)*P(N2|Q1). For the first pick there are 2 quarters out of 4, so you are right that P(Q1)=2/4. Given that the first coin was a quarter, there are 3 coins left, two of which are nickels, so P(N2|Q1)=2/3. The answer is therefore (as you selected) 2/4*2/3=1/3.

Incorrect. We are looking for P(Q1 and N2) and therefore need to use the General Multiplication Rule. P(Q1 and N2)=P(Q1)*P(N2|Q1). For the first pick there are 2 quarters out of 4, so P(Q1)=2/4. Given that the first coin was a quarter, there are 3 coins left, two of which are nickels, so P(N2|Q1)=2/3. The answer is therefore 2/4*2/3=1/3.
